There are many, many posts regarding sleep (of the lack of it) post-op so I thought I would share (again), my favourite post from Kate, a fellow forum member. It is invaluable advice especially for the newbies.
SLEEP CLUB
Hi everyone, I was looking back through some old posts trying to find one about constipation if all subjects (!) & I found Kate's post about sleeping. I'm sure she won't mind as I've took the liberty of copying it again. It was such a great read & made perfect sense particularly now I'm post -op.
As I now consider myself a hip guru after two THR's wink I thought I would impart my most considerable knowledge about sleeping post op.
So as you gather in closer to the screen to read I am going to poke you in the eye and tell you the first first rule...
1) There are no rules of sleep club
In fact there are so many rules of sleep club world wide that it would be hard to confine them all but we are all victim to our country, our county and surgeons particular cruelty (I mean surgical style) when it come to how we are supposed to sleep. Anterior, posterior and lateral scars all bring their own particular delights when trying to stop doing the twist in the early hours.
So, you can arm yourself with the latest in latex support pillows, V pillows, small hand embroidered cushions that Aunty Edna gave you, mattress toppers, wedges, sleeping tablets, pain relief, whiskey cocktail or a complete hospital bed but one thing isn't going to change - your healing!
Our lives before were clock driven , getting a good night's sleep before getting up for work was imperative. Lack of sleep meant we couldn't function properly.
Now, the God of New and Shiny Hip Implants has thrown all that up in the air and we don't know where we are!
We toss and turn (very carefully) waiting for the elusive sleep that never comes or comes in annoying one hour servings. You think you have slept all night only to find that barely ten minutes has gone by since you last looked at the clock. You hobble out of bed with one eye shut, trying to fool yourself into staying asleep while you have a midnight wee and you just know that if you lie there a bit longer then YOU MUST fall asleep.
As we all know things at night are magnified to horror proportions and the sweating, the pain, the twitching, the discomfort have all become mountains we cannot climb.
So, you have read this far and you are waiting for me to give you the secret to sleeping all through the night after having part of your leg chopped off and in a position that you detest. Sorry, I don't have have those answers but what I have learned is....
This lack of sleep, is it so bad? Are you hoping to go to work in the morning? Are you leaping out of bed to go hiking, on holiday, ice sking? No.
The best cure I can find for lack of sleep is - chill out, go with it, let it happen.
Goodness knows what healing is going on inside but it doesn't confine itself to happening at night. It is imperative to rest in the first 6 weeks as it is to walk and that rest can be feet up on the sofa or a few catnaps throughout the day.
I have no problems with lack of sleep because I don't care about it.
A six weeks (today) after my 2nd THR I have learned that it is all transient. Regular sleep comes back in a position that we favour eventually and the trick is to stop worrying about it.
I sleep most of the night now, waking up between 5.30 and 6.30am. Once you find that it okay to find a sleeping place all over the house you will sleep much better as well.I was more comfortable on the sofa this time so that's where I went.
I watched all the films that no one else wanted to watch and knew that I was getting back to normal when it took me five nights to watch a film.
So, wave yourself a magic wand, stop fretting, this is temporary and I'll even go as far as to say enjoy it. For those going back to work that will come soon enough and your body regulates very quickly so in the meantime give yourself a night break, chill out - a bowl of ice cream at 3am is really rather nice!

Hi I'm a 38 year old father, married, father of three kids. when out cycling with my eldest daughter at the beginning of April, we both came off resulting in a broken left hip for me, but fortunately not a scratch on my daughter.
I had a vertical fracture on my left Femur, leaving the ball separated. The surgeon reattached it with 3 titanium bolts, with hope of the bone fusing back together. But as the fracture was vertical, he only gave it a 30% chance of success.
Even though the repair was completed only nine hours after the accident and me following the non use of the leg for six weeks, followed by six weeks of touch bearing only. The bone did not fuse. Touch bearing was very painful and I could feel the bone rubbing.
Four weekly XRays showed the bone had partially collapsed after the initial operation, but the type of bolts were keeping it all tight together. The down side was that my left keg was now nearly an inch shorter than it had been before, any use if my left keg showed a pronounced limp.
I had a CT scan at the end of July to check progress and the straight of the Femur was beginning to callous over and the ball was starting to collapse. There was evidence of fibrous tissue between the two main pieces of bone, but no bone regrowth.
I was in a lot of pain, with a cocktail of painkillers and other medication to counter side effects. My quality of life was much reduced and I was unable to do many things that I would do normally.
Maintenance of my house and garden has been completely left this year, so I haven't grown anything to pickle which is a family favourite. Neither have I been able to brew any beer, as I can't lift any of the barrels.
I am now two weeks post full hip replacement. With an uncemented ceramic hip. The op was done just two weeks after the decision was made. I had my private insurance involved, but they would only step in if the NHS couldnt do it within six weeks. My consultant also turned out to be one of their preferred surgeons.
My quality of life is already improved. Pain control is just paracetamol, I do get occasional pains the full length of my thigh, but that is after prolonged exercise. I am down to a single crutch for the majority of the time.
The hip replacement wasn't the original choice of my consultant due to my age. Sadly this has added to the problem. With four months of limited use, I have lost a lot of muscle mass in my left leg. The bone of my pelvis has reduced on my left side and will take time to get back to strength.
The biggest issue for me now is lack of sleep. Sleeping on my back leaves me with a painful back and the wound is still to uncomfortable to lay on for more than a few minutes.
To be honest, considering how much it has improved in the last two week I wish I had been able to have the replacement at the beginning.
I now want to get back to being active and able to get down and play with my son, who was two years old just two days before the accident.

Only now I also have outer hip pain.
Cortisone shots didn't help.
Surgeon sent me to a rheumatoid arthritis specialist who says I do not have rheumatoid arthritis. Surgeon says I probably have a hip replacement in my future.
I am now back at the pain clinic where they've had to raise my dose from 5 to 10 _325 hydrocodone

Hi All,
It is day three post op for me and things are going pretty well. I want to give a fairly detailed account of the last three days as reading this kind of thing really helped me prepare. Bearing in mind that everyones recovery will be different.
Day 0 - Operation Day
The hours following the op are a bit of a blur. I think I was in the theatre for several hours. When I came around I had very low blood pressure and this was consistent over the next 24 hours. Managed to stand and shift weight to my operated leg 6 hours after the operation. Had some nausea. Took a lot of pain killers through the night.
Day 1 - After Operation
Was spaced out for most of the day but thanks to ample pain killers was feeling pretty good. Managed to shower myself, only required assistance to put stockings back on. Managed to use crutches around the ward. By the afternoon I was cleared to go to the toilet on my own using crutches. This was probably my worse night pain wise.
Day 2 - After Operation
Crutched around the ward. Blood pressure returned to normal. Have full mobility with crutches. Passed the stairs test and getting in and out of car test. Pain eased off but still on pain killers periodically. First swelling started so began using ice packs. Able to do all lying and standing physio. Spent a few hours in a chair. Previous to the operation I could not sit for more than a few minutes without pain in the joint. Pain that would increase and become 10/10 until I got up and limped around. Now there is zero pain.
Day 3 - Today
Have woken this morning feeling fantastic. Went for a crutch around the ward. Swelling has reduced. My main problem is that I have been walking with a stiff hip for 20 or so years so having some difficulty getting the correct muscles to fire. This will come with time and effort. i am going home today.
There are some caveats on the above. I have been on around the clock pain killers which has hidden the pain and improved my general mood. And the worse may yet be to come. I have been advised that swelling and bruising are on the way.

Those who have been here a while may know that my 2 big toe nails stopped growing and the nail beds became very sore after my hip op. This was due to the quilt weighing down on them (my big toes being considerably longer than the others). I eventually bought a bed cradle though too late to stop the damage. After a visit to the nurse I was told they would start growing again but it could take months. I had to wear canvas shoes as I couldn't stand any pressure on them.They did indeed finally start to grow about 6 months after the operation . A couple of months later I noticed something a bit odd. The bottom of the nail had come away from the nail bed and a new nail was growing underneath. The new nail is now just under half way up the length of the whole nail and now the old nail is about 3mm from the bottom. Looks like it will take at least another 8 months for the new one to get to the top - presumably the old one will just fall off. It's still a bit sensitive. I suppose it's the new one forcing its way up!
May be this is one of the weirdest side effects there is!
Any way any hippies who sense their toenails getting sore as they have to sleep on their back - get a cradle before it's too late!
Now I'm 9months post op I will be saying goodbye to the forum. Time to focus on getting on with life. There are plenty of new people to help the latest hippies as there were for me so this is my last post which may be of use to someone.
My hip is pretty good though the tissue around the scar and trocanter are still a bit too sore to lie on - no probs in the day though. I should be getting an xray in a couple of months so fingers crossed that will go well.
Good luck everyone with their ops and recovery.

Hi fellow hippies old and new!
Some of you may remember me from what seems like a million years ago -such a long journey.
I am 64 years old, very active and work full time
I had my RTHR  with Michael Cronin at Coventry Hospital using Superpath method of surgery on 10th June 2015, following a very long wait and much pain and limping and lurching around.
I recovered quickly and have had an excellent result - the operation gave me my life back.
Went for my annual check with Michael Cronin last week. He said that hip was even better than when he operated on me. No movement in joint at all and because I had non cemented implant, bone had grown round it and was very strong and secure. Movement in the joint is excellent. Sometimes I cannot believe I had this operation as my hip feels perfectly normal and it just seems to get better and better. In fact I have noticed a real improvement over the last 3 months
Michael Cronin is now training other surgeons to do this pioneering Superpath surgery so hopefully more people will benefit from it.
So to all of you out there in the worried and nervous pre op phase and going through the painful early days/sleepless nights post op, it does get so much better and I am so glad I had my op. There was never any doubt in my mind - I had to have the op if I was to ever lead a normal life again!
I feel reborn and can do almost everything I could do before.
Still need to have a bit of physio on muscles in unoperated hip/ leg from all the bad walking practices pre op but I am so grateful to my wonderful surgeon for his skill and expertise in getting me sorted out.
Have faith that you will get well, religiously do your exercises. Yes, you will have rough days in the early stages and wonder how you will ever get back to how you used to be. Be patient, be positive, never ever lose heart. Your attitude is all important in you getting well
I wish all of you the very best for the future. Use this wonderful forum - it got me through many sleepless nights in the early days. Some very kind and supportive folk on here
Kindest regards Linda

Or a light hearted look at post op issues:
1.       You will pee for England (or insert your country here) for at least a week.  Be prepared cos you just won稚 be able to control yourself.  If you don稚 have a loo near your bedroom, invest in a bucket and pretend you池e glamping.
2.       You will only have the attention span of a gnat.  If you had planned on catching up on reading and/or all those box sets, forget it.  As soon as you start concentrating on that book or the first episode of the box set, you will be asleep.
3.       Be prepared to fall asleep at any point during the day.  At night you won稚 be able to get to sleep at all.
4.       Get used to the fact that you値l have to (not) sleep on your back.  I know very few people who actually sleep on their back by choice.  It is a really uncomfortable position and will result in getting backache after a few hours.
5.       Make sure you have short toenails, especially on the big toes as the pressure from any bedclothes will hurt toes and your heels.
6.       Compression socks  so sexy and comfortable  not.  They are an essential fashion accessory for 6 weeks for all hippies.  Surely they must be classified as a form of torture!
7.       Your operated leg will feel like it weighs a ton for the first week.  It also feels like it doesn稚 belong to you. It will get better.
8.       Don稚 tell your spouse/family/friends about your op in detail.  They really aren稚 that interested and it would be nice if family/friends visited more than once.  Best to just post on to this forum.
9.       Don稚 believe the adverts  pre-prepared meals are terrible.  The actual contents have only a passing semblance to the packet photo. The ingredients used are usually the cheapest the manufacture can get away with.  To add insult to injury the portion size is for a child.
10.   Any chocolates/sweets/puddings eaten during your recovery period are deemed to be non-fattening  and don稚 listen to anyone who tells you otherwise.
  Feel free to add to the list

After she initially fell my uncles who lives in China (but not with her) thought she simply sprained her leg, so she was just bedridden for an entire month. My sister who lives the states went to visit her a month ago and discovered that she still bedridden and was in a lot of pain and decided to take her to the hospital for a checkup. It was discovered that she broke her hip (Intracapsular Fracture, the ball of the femur is broken). So due to negligence from my uncles she was left untreated for over a month. For the past month my sister and I have been trying to convince our grandmother to do a partial hip replacement.
She just did a physical and her organs are all in good shape and healthy, and deemed quite fit for hip replacement surgery. However, she is extremely afraid of the surgery and was reluctant to participate. In addition, one of the uncles refuse to let her do surgery because he believes that she値l heal somehow and be able to sit again, and that the after effects of the surgery is not something he wants to deal with (if things go wrong). However I managed to convince her to do the surgery if I go back (I live in Canada) to see her through the surgery and early stages of recovery.
My grandmother has osteoporosis a bad knee and this newly broken hip. Before she broke her hip she could walk with assistance by using a walker or holding the wall, but not for long. For example she could go to the bathroom by herself or went to the shelf to get something. For majority of the day she alternates between sitting and laying down (probably about 50/50). Today she is mostly bedridden, she probably cannot sit for more than 1 hour before pain becomes unbearable. So she only sits up for her meals.
My thinking is that even if she somehow manages to sit up, it痴 still gonna take her another few month bed ridden until she can sit upright, whereas after surgery she can sit up in days. I don稚 have much hope for her to walk again but I figured sitting sooner has to be better for her health because I致e confirmed with multiple doctors that bedridden increases your chances of having organ failure significantly. So if she does the surgery and successful recovery, her chances of living another few more years increases significantly.
Based on what I described do you think she should get the replacement? Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

This is a question that I thought might be useful for up-and-coming hippies.
For clarification, these possible benefits and amounts are only relevant if you live in England  Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland may differ.
My understanding is this  if you池e employed then you will be signed off for a number of weeks (which will depend on your own personal recovery rate) and for those weeks you will be paid occupational sick pay (as per your employment contract) if you池e lucky, or statutory sick pay of ｣88.45 p/w (for 2016/17) if you池e not quite so fortunate. If you池e self-employed, it痴 just tough luck and you get nothing, though you could be eligible for ESA.
ESA (Employment and Support Allowance) is another benefit which is available to both employed and self- employed and is worth ｣73.20 p/w for over 25s.  If eligible if will also entitle you to help with your Council Tax.  Please note that this benefit is based on both you and your spouse/partner痴 income.
The ESA does seem to involve jumping through quite a few hoops and should probably be instigated before surgery.

This was my 6 week review at 8 weeks and the news is good.  I am now walking without a stick and no limp! I have very little pain - more of a muscle ache, especially when I over do it - and no need for any pain medication. The restrictions have been lifted - so goodbye to that lovely (but useful) item in the bathroom, the raised toilet seat. I also received a warning about still being careful bending at the hip for the next 6 weeks. No real worries with that, my hip soon lets me know if I'm doing something it doesn't like!
The bad news is that my other hip (which hadn't been hurting despite also showing severe OA on the x-ray), is now beginning to hurt.  The surgeon is going to keep an eye on it with regular follow up appointments (the next one in December) but suspects I will have to have it replaced at some point next year.  He did add that he would be only too pleased to be proven wrong (me too).

There are many, many posts regarding sleep (of the lack of it) post-op so I thought I would share (again), my favourite post from Kate, a fellow forum member. It is invaluable advice especially for the newbies.
SLEEP CLUB
Hi everyone, I was looking back through some old posts trying to find one about constipation if all subjects (!) & I found Kate's post about sleeping. I'm sure she won't mind as I've took the liberty of copying it again. It was such a great read & made perfect sense particularly now I'm post -op.
As I now consider myself a hip guru after two THR's wink I thought I would impart my most considerable knowledge about sleeping post op.
So as you gather in closer to the screen to read I am going to poke you in the eye and tell you the first first rule...
1) There are no rules of sleep club
In fact there are so many rules of sleep club world wide that it would be hard to confine them all but we are all victim to our country, our county and surgeons particular cruelty (I mean surgical style) when it come to how we are supposed to sleep. Anterior, posterior and lateral scars all bring their own particular delights when trying to stop doing the twist in the early hours.
So, you can arm yourself with the latest in latex support pillows, V pillows, small hand embroidered cushions that Aunty Edna gave you, mattress toppers, wedges, sleeping tablets, pain relief, whiskey cocktail or a complete hospital bed but one thing isn't going to change - your healing!
Our lives before were clock driven , getting a good night's sleep before getting up for work was imperative. Lack of sleep meant we couldn't function properly.
Now, the God of New and Shiny Hip Implants has thrown all that up in the air and we don't know where we are!
We toss and turn (very carefully) waiting for the elusive sleep that never comes or comes in annoying one hour servings. You think you have slept all night only to find that barely ten minutes has gone by since you last looked at the clock. You hobble out of bed with one eye shut, trying to fool yourself into staying asleep while you have a midnight wee and you just know that if you lie there a bit longer then YOU MUST fall asleep.
As we all know things at night are magnified to horror proportions and the sweating, the pain, the twitching, the discomfort have all become mountains we cannot climb.
So, you have read this far and you are waiting for me to give you the secret to sleeping all through the night after having part of your leg chopped off and in a position that you detest. Sorry, I don't have have those answers but what I have learned is....
This lack of sleep, is it so bad? Are you hoping to go to work in the morning? Are you leaping out of bed to go hiking, on holiday, ice sking? No.
The best cure I can find for lack of sleep is - chill out, go with it, let it happen.
Goodness knows what healing is going on inside but it doesn't confine itself to happening at night. It is imperative to rest in the first 6 weeks as it is to walk and that rest can be feet up on the sofa or a few catnaps throughout the day.
I have no problems with lack of sleep because I don't care about it.
A six weeks (today) after my 2nd THR I have learned that it is all transient. Regular sleep comes back in a position that we favour eventually and the trick is to stop worrying about it.
I sleep most of the night now, waking up between 5.30 and 6.30am. Once you find that it okay to find a sleeping place all over the house you will sleep much better as well.I was more comfortable on the sofa this time so that's where I went.
I watched all the films that no one else wanted to watch and knew that I was getting back to normal when it took me five nights to watch a film.
So, wave yourself a magic wand, stop fretting, this is temporary and I'll even go as far as to say enjoy it. For those going back to work that will come soon enough and your body regulates very quickly so in the meantime give yourself a night break, chill out - a bowl of ice cream at 3am is really rather nice!

Yes, it's true the ortho had an opening for surgery one week after we went for the 4-month postop on the LTHR.
Let's back up a bit, though. At the previous appointment, son had an MRI to see if there was AVN in the non-operated hip. He was crushed to find out that was the case. We had already discussed the alternative to THR - core decompression. I had researched this and learned it only worked for a very few people, only for a few years, and they ultimately had to have THR. CD is more painful post-surgery, also takes longer to recover from, and you need to wait a year to know if it was successful. Knowing all of this, it was NOT an option.
However, son started the discussion with the orho about the success rate. Surgeon admittled it was 40% effective AT BEST. We asked, well what about those patients who you've done this procedure on? 
The ortho said he operated on a 12 y/o boy who ended up having a THR done by another surgeon. (He looked defeated as he said this.) Son then asked what it would take for him to have the RTHR. "Time" doctor said, then realized how ridiculous that was for ANYONE. Including a 12 y/o boy. He really convinced himself!
At that point dr said he had an opening next week. In reality it took another week, because they were short-staffed that week. In the meantime I got the runaround from my own insurance company, when in fact no prior approval was necessary because it was same day surgery - no hospital stay involved because son qualified for the program where you leave the hospital after recovering sufficiently from anesthesia. Then you make your own way across the highway to the Hilton, where you stay for 2 nights. A nurse is down the hall and comes in to give you your meds, take your vitals, etc. A PT person comes the next day, as does the doctor's assistant. Son could have showered the next day, and the nurse helps if you need it. 
No oxycodone, so no waterfall sweats, crazy itching, dizziness. Spinal, so no 4-month fog. 
So, be sure to refuse any drugs you've had a bad interaction with - these just delay your getting well. And please do your research before taking the word of a doctor. Remember they are only speaking in generalities. And it's likely none of them have had any of these procedures. 
We had 6 questions for the surgeon:
1) LLD - yes, right several mm shorter than left - x-ray shows this. I think surgeon was a little regretful at this.
2) When can son get dental surgery he needs (this is a whole other story that probably includes a dentist's incompetence. I haven't sued anyone yet, but that may change) At first ortho said 3 months, but because it involves son's general health - ANY TIME.
3) In your experience, does AVN affect other joints? Only in the case where the patient has had a transplant. They take anti-rejection drugs which have side effects.
4) Please check my hematoma. Greatly reduced - not a problem now.
5) I am relocating, do you know any ortho in my new area? Sorry, no. I would check you in a year, so you will want to have the new ortho do so.
6) Can son exercise on machines now, at 3 weeks? Yes - stationary bike, elliptical, even treadmill (that seems DANGEROUS to me!) 
Sorry for the book I've written. I can't come here often, as our move is imminent, and so much to do. And I've just had dental discomfort, found mysel a competent dentist, got a temporary crown (it's a molar). And a haircut, which you all know is important to mental health! LOL
So son is doing well, a double hippie like so many of you. I'll still keep an eye on you. Have the THR, you will have the incision pain, and recovery to get through, but it will let you move on with the rest of your life.
Love & Aloha,
Soos

After 7 months of pain, physical therapy, limping, weakness in my leg, not sleeping, I had an MRI which showed glut tears, labrum tear and lots of arthritis in my hip. 4 days ago I had a diagnostic injection of cortisone and numbing stuff under fluoroscopy deep into the hip joint to separate the glut pain from the arthritis. Getting some relief in weakness and hip pain, but gluts still painful and restrict a full step when walking.  We talked about an anterior hip replacement, which I hear most docs are doing here in the US.  The recovery is shorter and since they don't cut muscles to insert the implant, there is no restrictions or PT after. Scar is hidden by underwear elastic, which would appeal to a younger patient. He said he would repair the tendons at that time.  Question  I can't seem to find any information about how the gluts repairs are sutured to a metal femoral head. I do find info on repairs after THR, but that's 2 surgeries.  I realize every patient is different in the exact tear, size, etc, but I want to know more before I sign up, and the notes I read on this forum and so informed and helpful I hope someone out there has some thoughts or info to share. a homeopathic doctor recently gave me this advice and I thought I'd share it with my fellow hippies, I've already started to follow this advice I'm 2 weeks post op.
So, this Doctor told me that calcium is very important for healing bones ( my femur also got fractured in my thr surgery), but apparently the body struggles to absorb calcium in tablet form, he suggested the following.
buy some organic eggs, when you have used the eggs wash the shells and then boil them for 10 minutes and leave them overnight to dry, once dry grind them in a pestle and mortar, or better still a coffee grinder or nutribullet if you have one, when they are a fine powder store them in an airtight jar or Tupperware and sprinkle a teaspoon full each day on food maybe your morning porridge, in my case I add a spoonful to my morning smoothie...
As I said I don't know if this works, but it sounds like it should and I have it on good authority that it does.

My femoral nerve was damaged 12 months ago. I had a straightforward THR, but it slipped out ( no fall, nothing) after 3 nights and following the revision, my femoral nerve was damaged. Athough I could 'feel' more after 4 months, I was on crutches for 6 months, unable to drive for 5. Then it seemed to improve, until the knee suddenly swelled up horribly and felt scarily unstable. I had an MRI scan, waited ages for the result and it seems that the swelling is just fat, which is simply more noticeable because my quads and VMO have atrophied so badly because of the femoral nerve injury. Has anybody else had the same experience? Can anybody tell me how long it took for the quads and VMO to start working again? Which exercises worked?
12 months on, I can walk without crutches on flat ground, but as I also have chronic arthritis in the knee on the opposite leg ( needed a replacement knee years ago, but they said I was too young...I'm only 54), I cannot walk very far or stand for long without intense pain and discomfort. Steps are hell and I have to use my arms to pull/support me. Luckily, I can cycle, which I do every day. But I'm becoming extremely depressed. Yes, my son has joined your club - 2 hips done in 4 months! The story of what happened to make the doctor change his mind will have to wait for another time.
Each hip experience is SO different. I think it took son THREE MONTHS to emerge from the fog because of general anesthesia AND he was in such a debilitated condition prior to surgery. But, he didn't have much incision pain. He had a spinal this time, and instead of taking four hours to be conscious enough to leave, he had clarity in an hour, and along with it, pain. 
But today he has not taken any narcotics, but did feel a bit hungover this morning. He is taking acetaminophen and naproxen. 
Yesterday, he went to a meeting on campus and walked 6 blocks to and from. He was not in pain, but he was so tired and had discomfort. It was 95F feels like 108 yesterday. He is not walking properly - stride to short - but does not use his cane. sigh. Today he went for a deep tissue massage, and thought it helped.
Hippies, if you've had a bad allergic reaction to oxycodone, DO NOT LET THEM GIVE IT TO YOU AGAIN! Son had the waterfall sweats, itching and dizziness from this with the first hip. So he told everyone he could he did not want this. Instead they gave him a low dose of hydromorphone. After ten days, we started splitting them. Yes, we know you're not supposed to. We even split the oxycontin. It just made it easier to taper off.
Here's the downside: with all that clarity comes worry. And the crazy busyness involves us moving out of the present apartment into interim accomodations while his belongings go to the west coast. Who knew they have a hospital rate? We'll stay in them for a month, then fly away from this place. I am going crazy trying to find a short-term place to stay there, as well as an apartment for son to rent. Yesterday I asked a friend there for help, and he has already come through with some ideas. Unlike this place where people smile and say things, but could care less.
Okay, sorry TMI. Just how do you hippies recover alone? With meds to figure out, dressing to change, cooking and eating? At least my son has a personal assistant to do the laundry, and today she vacuumed and mopped! That would be ME! 
Son has an appointment with the surgeon Monday. The nurse who took his staples out kindly set it up as we are leaving so soon. Son is worried that there is Leg Length Discrepancy. And there is a hematoma to be aspirated. 
Hope you are all doing well, and not bored to death. 
Aloha, Soos

managing stepping up stairs with my operated leg once I have got moving. Down to one anti inflammatory a day (for my other hip!)
no painkillers. 
Walking up to two miles most days. 
Still have some discomfort, butt pain and soreness/ tenderness around the wound site. So when I rest I get my feet up and apply ice. Think lounging on raised sofa binge watching House of Cards on Netflicks!
Back to cooking for the whole family, washing and a bit of half hearted cleaning. Have told husband I am not allowed to use the vacuum cleaner for at least three years!!!!!
I am so glad to have had the opportunity of this surgery and will not hesitate to have the other hip done as soon as it needs it. 
Even the Spinal which I was worried about ( thanks for all your reassuring comments!) was brilliant. Will have it again. 
To be honest the whole thing has been easier than I thought, although I have had my moments it has definitely been worth it. 
Thank you all, I am so glad I found this forum. 
Thank you Graham for your Laymans Guide. It is a realy good resource. 
One more week of hip precautions/ restrictions and I realy don't mind. 
Take care all new hippies, go slowly and steadily we all want our brand new hips to last as long as possible. 
As mine is uncemented I felt I needed to give it time to "bed" in and for bone to grow, I don't think you can rush that. 
Think I am rambling on a bit now. 
Healing Fairy Dust to all. ??
Kris. X

Hi all: Just thought I would update my situation. I am now 12 weeks post op but having a lot of back pain, pain in both hips and legs plus headaches. This was rough as after last week, when I went on a great hike, I thought I was at the breakthrough stage.
Anyway, after much pain, worry and discomfort, I went to Emergency and luckily my own M.D. was the physician on site.
My x rays are fine. He thinks I have some issues with soft tissue related to misalignment of my hips and my body's over compensation by my right side muscles and tendons, now causing pain and inflammation of both hips, legs and hips. So, I have a prescription for pain meds Tramadone, advised to rest for a few days and then get back to exercising and healing.
I have set up an appointment with the Orthpaedic surgeon for Thursday.
For other hippies, I am echoing Maloo's advice not to overdo it.
Also, if you think something is not right in your recovery, go see the Orthopaedic surgeon or your M.D. 
Cathy

I知 very pleased to report that recovery is going well.  I am managing to walk unaided in the house  most of the time, and have a walking stick for when I知 feeling tired and need a bit of help.
I still tire easily and am only managing to work a couple of hours a day (followed by a snooze), but that痴 mainly because I work for myself, so I don稚 get paid if I don稚 work.  The tiredness is decreasing and I hope that by the time my 6 weeks are up I should be working longer, but will have to wait and see.
I知 also managing to sleep on my operated side now for most of the night, which has dramatically increased the quality of my sleep.  I do not sleep well on my back! I am looking forward to being able to sleep on my good side (my usual side) in a couple of weeks (hopefully).
Physiotherapy  unfortunately I知 not in an area which automatically schedules physiotherapy and as I was concerned that I wasn稚 doing the exercises correctly, I sought professional advice.  Though the physio was polite, she agreed that I wasn稚 doing the exercises properly and she gave me a couple of others to do as well (see separate discussion).  Not cheap as the physio had to come to my house, but well worth it.  I will continue with further sessions once I can drive.
To those who are waiting for their op and are nervous (so was I, see my very first discussion), quite simply having the op was one of the best things that I致e ever done.  I have gone from being in constant pain and barely able to walk to being able walk upright, with very limited short term pain.  I also know that this pain is only the result the operation and will stop - hopefully in the very near future.
My thanks to this forum once again for all it's support and useful information.

From what I have learned infection is a big worry especially as the prosthesis as a foreign body, unlike natures own joints, cannot self heal and the damage from infection to surrounding tissue is a  very serious problem.
I am especially worried because I have that age condition of thin papery skin which bleeds so easily at the slightest knock ,with patches of blood and bruises under the skin. Even tucking the sheets in on my bed can cause the skin to split and bleed.
I also have had several root canal treatments,the latest of which has never felt quite right.
I understand that infection can enter the blood supply via cuts,root canal treatments even hygienist tooth cleaning.
I get regular check-ups and 6 monthly hygienist care,but I am still quite anxious about this problem.
Do any of you have any experience or wisdom to offer on this topic?
Many thanks in advance. I have learned so much on this amazing site so hope for some enlightenment on this subject.
Hope you are all doing well whatever stage you are at.
Best wishes everybody
Joyx

Good morning All.  Today is my new hip's 4-week birthday!  I feel like I'm progressing well.  I still walk with a cane or a crutch inside my condo.  Outside I use a walker.  I've been advised to keep using the walker to ensure that I don't develop a limp.  I limped for so long before that surgery, they don't want that old muscle-memory to take over.  
I have very little pain (and now the rash is subsiding).  If I try walking without a cane, I just feel a bit scared I think.  Or not the most stable.  So there is probably still some weakness to muscles.  I do my exercises regularly and I do 3 - 10 minute walks each day -- either up and down my condo hallway or outside.  No pain!!!!
I see my surgeon next week.  We'll do new X-rays so it will be interesting to see those and to hear what he has to say.
One of the best things about this recovery has been this forum.  So helpful.  Hugs to all,
Leslie

hi all.  I have been for my 1 month check up today.  My specialist said I have made an excellent recovery so far.  He wants me to keep using the one crutch while outdoors for another two weeks but I'm ok to walk unaided indoors.  So I will do as I'm told and listen to the expert.  He said I'm fine to sleep on the operated side but not the good side for the time being.   I can drive and also start swimming the front crawl which I'm really pleased about as swimming is my thing . Also I can go on the static bike and cross trainer.  So, I'm really pleased with myself and looking forward to getting on with my recovery. Sorry I've been MIA - probably been weeks since I've been on here. Been 4 months since son's LTHR. When he went for his 6 week check he had an MRI which showed the start of Avascular Necrosis in his right hip. He was devastated. He survived going to a conference 2 flights and a total of eleven hours away. Some conference days were 9 hours long, and he needed his cane and was knackered at the end of them. But I was so proud to hear his presentation and the confidence he showed in knowing his subject, as well as answering questions. 
I learned (after being too long on the phone with some ignorant insurance people and not from them) that the surgery program he qualifies for does not even require preauthorization because as soon as he's had enough time out of surgery & anesthesia, he doesn't stay in the hospital. Instead, we go across the highway to a hotel and recover there for 2 nights. Here's a slightly different plan, and if the link doesn't pass the moderators, you can search for "hotel recovery for hip replacement surgery". 
http://www.buffalonews.com/business/patients-get-a-recovery-suite-not-a-hospital-bed-after-this-new-joint-replacement-surgery-20150613
The nurse is either down the hall or in the adjoining room. This is only for patients who are otherwise healthy, don't have cardiac issues and not covered by Medicare. A hotel room is preferable to a shared hospital room. You must have someone stay with you - poor son, his mother is his roommate! The nurse does check those squeezy electronic socks, make you cough & use the spirometer, take temperature & blood pressure & administer meds. And room service is Caesar salad, a burger & fries, or eggs and bacon!
Son is scared. NOT of the surgery (I am too much of a sissy to watch it in real time on video screens!) but the RECOVERY. Like many of you, he still gets VERY tired, being out and about for too long will mean he needs a full next day of rest.
Not sure how much I can be here, as it is T-6 days. And counting. I see your posts and try to vote on them. And I am thinking of you all. I don't know your pain, but I see my son's. The struggle is real.
P.S. - someday I will tell the story of how we got the surgeon to say yes.
Love, Soos

I realized that my anterior scar was beginning to create a low ridge and that I had some pain in my affected leg.  I have been using lotion and castor oil and deep massage to break down the tightness of scar ridge.  I have also enlisted the help of my PT to help with deep linear and circular massage along the scar line.  This has signficantly reduced pain in that area and added to the flexibility of my right leg.  I didn't connect the thickening scar ridge to discomfort I was experiencing in my leg until I realized the quick rate at which the scar was thickening in height.

Well i thought id do a quick update story for all the newbies and anyone whose after a long read xD
Well I was born on the 7th of Feb 1996 (That makes me 20 years old now) in Sunderland hospital which is also the hospital I go to for my medical stuff.
3rd October 1996; Diognosed with congenital hip dysplasia
1997; 3 surgeries
1998; Removal of metal work operation and another seperate surgery
2001;3 surgeries
2004; surgery
2007;removal of growing plate in right knee
2008;Removal of growing plate in right knee
11th April 2016; Complex thr, hip lowering and muscle lengthening
I also forgot completely that before this surgery i had avascular necrosis, i only remembered when my physio mentioned it when she read my notes, mind you im sick of health care professionals saying 'my, your young for a hip replacement' you work in medcine, you should no life isnt simple xD
so iv got surgery on the 30th of June provided nothing goes wrong, i will be having my right collar bone snapped and pin and plated and a piece of myright hip will be removed and inserted in the collar bone. This means i have to come off my crutches very quickly, im not ready but no choice. My pain levels are still ridicuously high in the operated hip and i think my back has been made worse and obvs still needing double knee replacments in the future because of the OA. Im using no crutches in the house but my gait is horrendous but the more i do it im sure it will improve, one crutch on short journeys and 2 on long journeys like tomorrow when i go to the metro centre for the first time since surgery without my wheelchair. Very nervous and excited.
So 2 days ago I went on a bus ride to a local shop to get food for the lizards, i wason crutches and the bus driver had parked quite far away from the curb so it was a very high step to get onto the bus, he made no attempt to help me or lower the bus. That was the first thing that annoyed me, so i paid and began walking to my seat whenthe driver pulls away before I had gotten to my seat, i flew forward and caught onto one of the poles but twisted my leg and hip which was agony. Anyone else noticed that bus drivers are incredibly ignorant?

Hi everyone, I am a 20 year old student who is finishing up a finance degree and is scheduled for two total hip replacements during summer break. I have had difficulty finding anyone around my age who has ever been in a similar situation, but I would certainly like to hear from a younger person who has experienced THP.
I was reluctant at first to have the operation done, as I would prefer to work in finance over the summer, but my surgeon believes I will not have much of a choice. Right now, even things like standing in a line or walking a rather short distance requires a lot out of me. I was diagnosed with a rare form of skeletal dyspepsia back in 2002, after years of testing to find a diagnosis for my pain. My cartilage has mostly worn away, and my pelvic bone has grown in an abnormal shape. The left joint replacement will be a specially engineered joint because the standard artificial joints will not fit correctly.
Fortunately, this problem has not heavily impacted the quality of my studies, as I have still managed to be a good student and have been able to still work quite a bit. I do get nervous about the surgery, but I take comfort in knowing that my family and significant other will be there for me during recovery. Fortunately, because of my younger age and relatively good flexibility, I hope that my recovery will be smooth.
As mentioned before, I would love to hear from a younger person who has experienced THP but also any person who could give me some support, encouragement and general tips would be very appreciated.

Hi friends
Well l start this with my heading. Will it ever be the same it was. I am starting to think not.
A lot of time has passed since my both my hip replacements 6 months from 1st 4 months from 2nd. Mentally l feel exausted with all the things that are going on in my life and there does not seem to be a light at the end of the tunnel for me.
Let me tell you my life in past 6 years.
Me and my husband were trying for a family at that time l was 36 nothing was happening naturally and we had to go down the route of IVF where l found out it was me that was not producing eggs normally. So l went through 1 round of IVF which was unsucessful. By this time l was classed as to old to get it on the NHS although l had started trying before the cut of age of 36 the waiting list was to long to l ended up missing cut of point and had to pay for it out of our savings. I was so desperate for a family we tried again and its hard going on your body you have to wait 6 months inbetween trying to let your body recover. 2nd time around no luck again. Again l was still yearning for my own family it was torture. We had one last try after eating through most of our saved money this time sucess l had just turned 40 and l said at the start if l had not fell pregnant by the time l turned 40 l was giving up. But to our amazment l was pregnant.....l never thought l would say those words l am pregnant. It was short lived as l miscarried at 7 weeks. My world fell apart. I had to grieve and accept the fact that this was my life luckily l have a great husband who helped me through this awful time it took me a year nearly 2 to get over it. It was a living hell.
I turned 42 and started getting a pain in my groin like l had pulled a mucsle at 1st it was bearable but always there l went to doctors who agreed it would be muscle related months past of me going to work with this pain and it steadily got worse l again returned to my doctors who sent me for xrays this time. That was november last year. A week later l was told l needed both hips replaced. BOTH . I was in shock l could not unerstand why l was not unhealthy or carrying extra weight l was normal. But the one lucky thing l did have was bupa through my work as a benifit ( private medical insurance) to you all not from.britain. i was seen a week or 2 later by surgeon who told me l had the nastiest looking hips he had seen and did not understand how l was still walking.
1st hip replaced 9th dec
2nd hip replaced 15th feb.
Have been in recovery ever since sometimes going well sometimes having a hard time. But l would say for both hips it was a pretty smooth recovery it might be taking longer than l though but l was walking everyday my PT was so happy with my progress they told me l did not need to be seen again. But like a lot of you l had up and down week some weeks feeling so low l would cry all the time some weeks feeling better and its been ongoing since then.
But and here is the but l have still been getting pains in my knee's when l was wallking and as times went by its been getting worse. I get really bad back pain as well. So off l go back to doctors who this time was the most horrible gp l have seen no empathy never even lifted his head to me in the room just stared at the computer and asked me why l needed my hips replaced so young!!!! I was shocked at him saying that as after being on this forum for so long l know l am not so young there are much younger people than me thats had thr's and was l meant to know the answer to that anyway!! I am not the doctor.
I asked him if l could have my hips and knee's xrayed as something was not right my recovery was dragging on l should be back at work by now but l am still waking in pain l still need painkillers.
1 week later l am called back to doctors Dr Horrible to be told my knee's are just as bad as my hips were. Severe scaring and OA in both.
So now folks before you all fall asleep reading my story even if you have given up half way through l am back to the hospital on wednesday to see knee surgoen. The same man that done my hips he will be sick of looking at me by now.
And in the midst of all that l have been attending hospital with my mum last week who has just found out she has cancer in her lung.
Why is life so hard. I am trying my best to stay posative for my mum l have to go to hospital today with her to see what her treatment is but it been a terrible 6 years for me. I am now 43 and l know l seem like a hard luck story. I am not looking for sympathy l just needed to get it all out my system by writing it down. I know there are people a lot worse off than me and l will get through this like l have got through everything else. I don't care about me at the moment l care more about whats happeening to my mum.
I am sorry for posting such a long story but l do ask myself will my life ever be the same? I don't think it will as l am a diffremt person now. I am sorry if it seems so doom and gloom l have got good parts in my life. A great husband and mum and dad and this forum has been invaluble to me.
I don't post threads a lot l tend to just try and offer advice or join in with other folks. But l am just sitting ar 5.15am in the morning thinking of my life and how it will end up.
Please don't let this put the newbies off hip replacements as they are a good thing. Its everything else thats going on in my life. Is it knee surgery ahead now. If so bring it on as l think l have hardened to things now as l am stronger than l was.
Again l apoligise for the life story but its helped me by just writing it.
Love you all
Laura
Xp

Hello,
I had a simple op at 8 yrs. Pins and a plate followed by a body cast. At 16
I had an op that was two parts. A bone graft was used to add surface area
(Support)to the socket. That didn't take so we tried again my senior year of
high school. Yup! Cap n' gown over body cast and crutches. Sweet! The 2nd
part of the op didn't seem to work either. My femur was sawn opposite the
femoral head. The piece was reattached to the femur slightly lower down.
The goal was to lengthen the muscle, tendons, ligaments that connect to
the pelvis. Does this sound familiar to anyone? I was told the procedure was
a success about 70% of the patients. My leg just got shorter. I'm not bitter.
I'm 50 years old. I was very active my whole life. The pain? Oh well. Today I
contacted my doctor. I hope to start pre-op soon. This forum is great! Thank
you all.

Hello, all.
I'm new here to this forum and would very much appreciate some advice from anybody who has experienced the same thing?
I'm a 53 year old female, and had a new hip in mid-April (due to dysplasia, probably congenital). I had been in great pain beforehand, and was really excited (sounds funny, but I was!) to have the operation as I was naively thinking I would be bouncing around again in no time. The operation went well, so my surgeon tells me (titanium and ceramic prothesis, frontal incision). I was lucky enough to be able to attend a three-week physiotherapy cure a month after the surgery, where I partipated every day in a number of targeted exercises (underwater exercises, individual physiotherapy etc). I met my goal and was able to walk without any support (crutches or stick) during my time there. Now I'm back at home, and finding that if I don't take a pain killer every day, I'm back to limping / waddling (you know the routine!). I'm so disappointed, as I thought that the surgery would take care of this. I am a 42 year old male who had perthes as a child. I have had some pain my entire life and the occasional flare ups but nothing too bad until 2 years ago. I have had a rapid deteriation since then and have for the first time in my life felt crippled for the last 6 months.
As I see it I have 2 sets of problems.
1. Osteo Arthritus of the hip joint. XRAYs and MRI show that I still have some good cartilage but that it is worn away to bone on bone in some areas. I have bone cysts and spurs on and under my femoral head. My hip joint cluncks and scrapes with every step. It sounds like a small bag of gravel. Walking more than a hundred metres is excrutiating. I have a pronounced limp.
2. Deformity of the femoral head. My femoral head looks like a squashed portobello mushroom. It is pockmarked and chipped and has bumps. It basically just doesn't work properly. My hip sticks out and my knee points in. I have an unusual gait that is wearing away my ankle tendons and the discs in my lower back. My left leg is 2.5cm shorter than my right leg. I have a shoe lift but it doesn't help with the function of the hip.
I have seen a surgeon a few times over the years and finally they have recommended THR. I am dissapointed that they are only able to use the posterior approach due to my deformity. I guess I am seeking to things on this forum.
1. Confirmation that my decision is justified. I am pretty sure it is.
2. First hand information on posterior total hip replacement in younger patients from someone who has been through it first hand.
I have included a couple of MRI images of my diseased joint.

Hi new and older hippies (?!)
i am passing on cumulative advice given to me by three different private specialists.
benefit....to strengthen hip muscles pre op, to maintain control if you slip or twist post op, to keep joint more secure for life.
To find your butt muscles -
lie on back with knees bent
squeeze butt cheeks to raise butt off floor a little
using hands, feel if thighs are engaged
if the thighs are engaged, you have not located just your butt muscles as they should work in isolation from the leg muscles.
try the action whilst feeling with your hands, as to which muscles are tightening
the ideal is to be able to lift very slightly off the floor, with relaxed thigh muscles.
another way to feel the correct muscles, is to lie in same position, lift one leg and hook inner hand behind knee from inner thigh area, and gently push leg against hand. Use the other hand on the outside of the buttock to feel whether the butt muscles are 'found' yet.
i practiced this for weeks before I could separate the butt from the thigh properly, and now use this exercise all the time,even when walking to keep them working.
I am convinced that my speedy recovery has been helped by preparing muscles for surgery.
if you are waiting for a date for surgery search Google for pre op exercises and start NOW
Happy butts! 
Jillx

How long did people have to wait for their hip replacements? This is a potted version of where I am at the moment, I hope I am not too boring. 
- Two years ago I was in the supermarket and felt faint, the next thing I knew I was flat on the floor surrounded by staff. I then discovered I could not stand by myself, but two burly shop assistants pulled me up and dumped me in a wheelchair. Came home and had terrible pain in top of right thigh.
- Went to an osteopath with GP approval, who worked on my right thigh. She said I might have a vascular problem as I had a heavy leg and it was painful to lift it up, so went to vascular surgeon with GP approval.
- A year ago Vascular surgeon said I had phlebitis in my right thigh and if I did not do something it would get much worse, so I had the main vein in my right leg removed and some little ones. Paid privately for VNUS Closure procedure and sclerotherapy, rather than vein stripping. It did not make a blind bit of difference to the heavy leg and pain, if anything it was worse. 
- Went to physio to try and relief the pain. She said it could be a nicked femoral artery and bursitis.
- Went to GP who referred me to another GP who can do steroid injections. He said it was not bursitis but could be a torn muscle. Suggested I had blood tests.
- GP said there was nothing he could do, but gave me paracetamol. I asked if I could have a scan, he said it would not help. I then said could I see a consultant privately. He gave me a phone number and said phone him.
- Made an appointment with consultant, GP gave consultant a letter saying I was fully mobile, and weight bearing. Minor muscle pain and it was my request to see the consultant! In fact the letter was rubbish. By this time I was in agony and pretty well housebound. 
- This week I saw the consultant, lay on the bed and in five seconds he sad "It's your hip". This was the first time anyone had mentioned the word HIP. 
- Had an x-ray, went back to consultant who said you need a hip replacement NOW or you will be in a wheelchair by Christmas as the whole hip joint is clobbered, he actually used medical terms to say that! I was gobsmacked. 
- I have discovered going privately is very pricey. How long will I have to wait for an operation on the NHS? The consultant is supposed to be writing to my GP. I am not sure what I should say to my GP apart I am not a happy bunny!

Hi all, 
I had my 6 week consultation and it went great.  Had another set of x-rays taken (I think I've definately had my quota for the next decade now!!) and it all looks fine.  The consultant has lifted all restrictions on me and has pretty much set me loose. The only permanent restriction he has given me is deep inflextion towards the opposite shoulder (i think thats the correct term) as he says that would almost definately dislocate it. Well I couldnt do that motion before surgery, so I dont think I will miss it! I'm allowed to drive and to start getting back to the gym. I got a copy of my x-ray.  It was so strange to see the implant in place!  I was also quite struck by how small the ball of the implant is compared to my natural hip joint! Its amazing that it actually stays in there. 
With regards to work he was quite keen to get me back next week, as such he's given me a sick note suggesting phased return - 50% for up to 4 weeks. He also wants me to phase out the crutch, so I have started practising today and so far so good....
You might be able to tell I am in a more positive mood than I was in my last post. Hopefully that will last.  I think the secret (as others said) is not to overdo it, otherwise it opens up a whole lot of pain.

So thats it for now I guess.  Follow up appointment booked for 6 months from now. 
David.

Hi everyone, I was looking back through some old posts trying to find one about constipation if all subjects (!) & I found Kate's post about sleeping. I'm sure she won't mind as I've took the liberty of copying it again. It was such a great read & made perfect sense particularly now I'm post -op.
As I now consider myself a hip guru after two THR's wink I thought I would impart my most considerable knowledge about sleeping post op.
So as you gather in closer to the screen to read I am going to poke you in the eye and tell you the first first rule...
1) There are no rules of sleep club
In fact there are so many rules of sleep club world wide that it would be hard to confine them all but we are all victim to our country, our county and surgeons particular cruelty (I mean surgical style) when it come to how we are supposed to sleep. Anterior, posterior and lateral scars all bring their own particular delights when trying to stop doing the twist in the early hours.
So, you can arm yourself with the latest in latex support pillows, V pillows, small hand embroidered cushions that Aunty Edna gave you, mattress toppers, wedges, sleeping tablets, pain relief, whiskey cocktail or a complete hospital bed but one thing isn't going to change - your healing!
Our lives before were clock driven , getting a good night's sleep before getting up for work was imperative. Lack of sleep meant we couldn't function properly.
Now, the God of New and Shiny Hip Implants has thrown all that up in the air and we don't know where we are!
We toss and turn (very carefully) waiting for the elusive sleep that never comes or comes in annoying one hour servings. You think you have slept all night only to find that barely ten minutes has gone by since you last looked at the clock. You hobble out of bed with one eye shut, trying to fool yourself into staying asleep while you have a midnight wee and you just know that if you lie there a bit longer then YOU MUST fall asleep.
As we all know things at night are magnified to horror proportions and the sweating, the pain, the twitching, the discomfort have all become mountains we cannot climb.
So, you have read this far and you are waiting for me to give you the secret to sleeping all through the night after having part of your leg chopped off and in a position that you detest. Sorry, I don't have have those answers but what I have learned is....
This lack of sleep, is it so bad? Are you hoping to go to work in the morning? Are you leaping out of bed to go hiking, on holiday, ice sking? No.
The best cure I can find for lack of sleep is - chill out, go with it, let it happen.
Goodness knows what healing is going on inside but it doesn't confine itself to happening at night. It is imperative to rest in the first 6 weeks as it is to walk and that rest can be feet up on the sofa or a few catnaps throughout the day.
I have no problems with lack of sleep because I don't care about it.
A six weeks (today) after my 2nd THR I have learned that it is all transient. Regular sleep comes back in a position that we favour eventually and the trick is to stop worrying about it.
I sleep most of the night now, waking up between 5.30 and 6.30am. Once you find that it okay to find a sleeping place all over the house you will sleep much better as well.I was more comfortable on the sofa this time so that's where I went.
I watched all the films that no one else wanted to watch and knew that I was getting back to normal when it took me five nights to watch a film.
So, wave yourself a magic wand, stop fretting, this is temporary and I'll even go as far as to say enjoy it. For those going back to work that will come soon enough and your body regulates very quickly so in the meantime give yourself a night break, chill out - a bowl of ice cream at 3am is really rather nice!

I'm a 55 yr old male who needed a THR due to many years of athletic activity and hard work. I, like others, had read alot of the bad experiences and put it off twice until I couldn't walk without a cane, couldn't get up out of a chair without turning sideways and pushing up off the chair arm. I was eating opoids like m and m's so I could go to work(construction) every day to save money for a possible 12 weeks off. It was BAD. My wife cried alot watching me grit my teeth every step and going to work. I had done alot of research, talked to several people who had it done. They had zero complications and were very encouraging and advised me to stay off any forums as most posts were negative experiences. So I opted on the anterior approach, and went thru with it May 11 2016. They did the spinal block and said I would just be sleepy and "May hear us talking, but would not feel a thing." They were right! After entering the OR loopy from the pre meds to relax me, the last things I remember were them asking me to sit up, 'lean forward and arch your back like a Halloween cat" the spinal was inserted, pain free and I laid back down. Their last words .."roll over on your left side" next thing I was opening my eyes in recovery. They gave me some ice to chew on, a pain shot, observation for 60 mins then up to my room. 2 hrs later I used a walker to use the restroom. 4 hrs later PT came in, got me up, used the walker, 2-300 steps. Mind you the spinal was still working full time. Anyway,, I was amazed! The surgeon came in to see me @7.30 am the next morning. I demonstrated I could walk with zero aid. He said after PT that morning, I could go home that afternoon if I wanted. I wanted! PT the next day, PT the next Mon, Wed and Friday. I had the exercises down pat. Never went back. I was sore(muscular) but never had joint pain. I went back to work on day 9 being careful not to do some specific movements to stay out of danger of dislocation. I have been working ever since and back in the gym 3-4 days a week. Today was week 4, zero issues. I am walking pain and limp free! I'm off(been off) the pain meds, and today were my last morning and afternoon 325mg aspirin for clot protection. Driving and working every day, pain free. I am astounded! I feel for those with post op issues, and I see there are many. I wanted to post my positive experience in hopes of encouraging others that it's not all bad. Albeit its only been 4 weeks, but I am very very happy to have my life back! Peace, love and prayers for all!

This is a bi fold gel mat, designed and sold for dogs to sit on  in Summer
it gets a bit cooler with light pressure. Lasts as long as it takes to get to sleep, and is so easy to slide under the back/hip area when you feel the wound warming up during the night. It reduces swelling too of course.
if you wake up hot again later, just swing it around for the other end to cool you down again.   It is totally reusable and cools down on its own.
ta da!
if you can't find one online, let me know and I will find out the name from the pet shop
hope this helps someone, somewhere
happy healing
jill

Hi all you very special and lovely people.  I hope everyone is getting on well with their individual recoveries.  This site has helped me so much before my op and  afterwards.
I am 7 weeks post op revision left hip surgery today.  I had my post-op check up at hospital this morning and came out feeling quite positive.  I had a lot of questions and worries that were answered by a lovely consultant.  She was so down to earth and friendly.
My original left hip plant needed to be taken out urgently because of problems (metal on metal hip resurfacing) and will in the future need the right hip implant to be taken out, but hopefully not for some time. I just want to get through this recovery and try and relax a bit and start enjoying my life.  It's been far too long since I've done that.
Now I  look back over the past few weeks and see what a journey the early weeks are and I see real improvements.  It was great to finish the injections (horrible things but necesssary), trying to get comfy in bed, on chairs, etc, getting those stockings off finally, being able to get around on one crutch, albeit limping around.  Getting into a car and going round the shops for a bit was really good - felt a bit normal.  Lots of things really.  I don't get chance to get on the site much but always read every post and I think you are all amazing people.  It really does feel like you have a close knitwork of friends and it's good to share knowledge and experiences and medical staff can't always answer, as brilliant as they are at fixing us.
Anyway, I wish you all a wonderful weekend and will try and post again real soon.
Love and hugs to you all from Pammyw.

I have decided to share my unfortunate experience.  On 4/23/16, I fell getting up out of a wobbly recliner in the late evening.  Fortunately, a friend wa there to help me get up.  I was also suffering from edema to both feet which prompted me to try to sleep in the recliner.  Though I was unable to`sleep, I waited the night through and took a cab to the emergency room.  During my emergency room evaluation, which i went there predominantly for the edema in myfeet, the ER Doc let me know that I had broken the ball off of my right femur in my fall the night before.  He called my orthopedic surgeon in to confer with me about moving up my hip replacement. The hip replacemet was attempted the following evning at th same hospital.  When I woke up in the Orhtopedic floor, I was told that the hip replacement didn't happen becuase when the surgeon lifted the broken femur head upt, he thought he saw pus.  Thus I was put on IV anitbiotics and am still on oral antibiotics awaiting an upcoming 2 week period of time to be antibiotic free after which my right femur fluid will be retesed for infection and ,if clear of infection, I can reschedule my right hip replacement. What worries me is the loss of lenght in my right leg nd the loss f muscl tome waiting to have the hip replacement.  My originally scheduled hip replacement was to have been last week.  My dilemna is not knowing how long I will have to wait to get th hip replacement.  A friend of my father's, another doctor, told me that what my surgeon may have seen could have been decomposed fat or bone marrow which occcurs when a bone is fractured.  So far, my bone has not tested positive for infection but I was immediately put on antibiotics.
I am curious if anyone else has had an eperience such as this.

I am now 6 weeks post op to the day and all is working well, I have not used sticks since week 3 and am walking fields, roads and parks with absolute ease, virtually no medication now just one IBrufen in the morning so feel clear headed again,  yesterday was the milestone for me as my daughter was married and I was desperate to be normal and to wear heels for her speial day,  Kitten heels were fine, and my husband and i love salsa dancing and yes albeit a little less active did our dancing to the delight and astonishment of our guests ,  today I have had my six week meeting with the surgeon who has delighted in my progress and although there were some negative comments on my lack of stic usage !  his response was that as long as you are confident and straight walking being sure to keep steps equal and balanced ,it can aid recovery because you are less dependant and clearly motivation and commitment are a huge part in post op progress.
I still have some discomfort and I am naturally cautious in what I do, I dont sleep well at all and my blood pressure is still very low 80/56 so I am not back to perfect health, however, I would just like to reassure those who are newly post op that I was desperately cncerned about getting moving but here I am in less tha 6 weeks living a really good and active life again. Modern medicine and these wonderful surgeons are true life changers , xxx

I am a 52-year-old woman who has had OA since my late 20's.  At the time, I was told that nothing could be done until I was much older.  So I started the Nsaid game, did injections, lost weight, and now I'm to the point that I need more relief.  I went to see a new doctor and he said it was time for them both to be replaced!  Even at my age, he feels that I may not need another replacement in my lifetime, and only time will tell.  Just to have the pain gone for one day would be amazing!  I was so excited the first time I had the injections.  I walked out with no pain for the first time in 25 years!  I lost my flexibility long ago, which is a hindrance to my life.  I know having the hips replaced will not give me back the flexibility, and I will have to work to have that.  I am curious to know what others have experienced in that area?
I found Coffeeman's discussion to be very helpful, and I believe there is another member that has a link out there as well.  I'm doing all the reading I can to try to keep myself calm!
My surgeon said he is doing the "superior" approach, that I was not the right body type (tummy's too big!! LOL) for the Anterior approach.  I'm hoping that this means I will not have as much pain from the incisions and cut muscles as the Posterior approach.  I will know more in a couple of days, I suppose.
I did buy risers for my recliner, and my hubby is going to put a riser under the couch since I'll have to sleep downstairs for a bit.  I'm nervous, but I'm prepared.  I know there is a lot of pain and discomfort in my near future, but I will come out on the other side so much better!
I am open to any suggestions at this point!
Thank you for taking the time to read this.

Had 2nd rthr on15th Feb 2016

Like someone once said on this forum nobody cares after 3 months and l don't mean you lot of hippies l mean people that don't understand hip replacement.

I work full time as a bank manager in a admin and call centre l have worked there for 13 going on 14 years.

I could go part time when l go back as there is no longer any need for me to have a full time job as we have no kids and our mortgage is paid off in sept. I meant to post this on Friday, but have been wrestling with a computer issue...
I had my almost-6-month check up on Friday. I was worried about it because at my February check I was told the surgeon had not actually repaired the fracture which led to my surgery in the first place. I was warned that necrosis could set in due to the lack of blood supply and it could all still collapse.
Well, had my x-ray on Friday and it's all good. The doctor even said the fracture area is still alive and even seems to be healing. There is still a possibility of collapse, but he told me that if it happens it will be gradual, not sudden, which was a huge relief.
I can still feel the gadgetry inside and it does still often feel heavy. I do still get pain, particularly if I walk too much or otherwise exert too much. But I'm feeling pretty good these days and about to do some volunteer tour guide work which will have me on my feet for hours on end.
I now don't have to go back until early December, so am feeling confident!

From door-to-door, travel took 13+ hours. I worried & couldn't get back to sleep when I didn't get a planned text at his 4am Seattle arrival, but was relieved to hear from him 4 hours later.
He checked in a huge case & small duffel, so we requested wheelchair assistance at curbside in Honolulu.They help him through TSA, & wheel him to the gate. At his final destination, the terminal is HUGE & the distance unreal. They wheel him from the door of the plane to the baggage claim then to ground transport. Easy if there's a golf cart available but ridiculous if it's a wheelchair & a case to maneuver. They earn their tips! Delta is SUPERB as far as assistance. And son has learned to accept help when he needs it. When he doesn't, he'll feel frustrated, exhausted & angry.
Tomorrow he sees his GP for a plan of action & an x-ray of the right, deteriorating AVN hip. Also to try to get answers & help with the ongoing tiredness & waterfall sweating. The following week he sees the surgeon who operated on his left hip for a 3-month check. He is hoping to have RTHR as soon as possible. If this surgeon won't do it, the GP will help him get a second opinion. Or we might attempt to pay for it out of pocket.
I'll be here in Hawaii for 3 more weeks, then I return to join my son, as he's asked me for help in making this happen.
Mahalo for listening. This is certainly a journey, & It continues. I learn so much from all of you here about determination, persistence, courage, kindness & support for each other.
Aloha, Soos

Its the middle of week 9 post op.  I was cleared to drive etc etc at week 6.  So that night I went back to work as a dancing teacher, although at a much lower number of hours than I usually do.  In NZ there is very little followup from a THR - the clearance meeting with my surgeon took about 10 mins, he showed me my xray, asked about my wound healing ( Id had a very bad time with my first THR - took 4.5 months for the wound to finally heal) told me my next followup appointment is in 5 years and bustled me out of the door.  So I'm doing rehab pilates, walking the streets of Auckland in 2/3 km slots and teaching dancing a couple of nights a week.  I'm also working with the best muscle therapy massage team around on a weekly basis.  I haven't tried high heels yet - and wont for a few more weeks.  I have to remind myself that its ONLY 9 weeks and I'm doing OK.  Everytime I try a "something" that I haven't done since before my THR it takes a while and take a bit out of me.  My danceing students are amazed at what I can do right now.  And I must remember to be amazed for myself, otherwise I could expect too much.
